original_theorem:
Let $f$ be defined on $[a,b].$ Then $f$ is continuous at $x_0$ in
$[a,b]$ if and only if $w_f(x_0)=0.$ $($Continuity at $a$ or
$b$ means continuity from the right or left, respectively.$)$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem continuous_at_iff_modulus_of_continuity_eq_zero {α : Type*} [LinearOrderedTopology α]
    {f : α → ℝ} {a b x₀ : α} (hab : a ≤ b) (hx₀ : x₀ ∈ Icc a b) :
    (ContinuousAt f x₀ : Prop) ↔ (Tendsto (fun δ => sSup { |f y - f z| | (y : α) (z : α), y ∈ Icc a b, z ∈ Icc a b, |y - x₀| < δ, |z - x₀| < δ }) (nhds 0) (nhds 0) : Prop) := by sorry
```

theorem continuous_at_iff_modulus_of_continuity_eq_zero {α : Type*} [LinearOrderedTopology α]
    {f : α → ℝ} {a b x₀ : α} (hab : a ≤ b) (hx₀ : x₀ ∈ Icc a b) :
    (ContinuousAt f x₀ : Prop) ↔ (Tendsto (fun δ => sSup { |f y - f z| | (y : α) (z : α), y ∈ Icc a b, z ∈ Icc a b, |y - x₀| < δ, |z - x₀| < δ }) (nhds 0) (nhds 0) : Prop) := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• For $x_0 \in (a,b)$, the oscillation $w_f(x_0) = \inf_{h>0} W_f([x_0-h, x_0+h] \cap [a,b]) = 0$ [tc_3, def_3].
• $\epsilon > 0$ is a positive real number.
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists an $h > 0$ such that $[x_0-h, x_0+h] \subset [a,b]$ and $W_f([x_0-h, x_0+h]) < \epsilon$ [l1].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• For a given interval $I$, $W_f(I) = \sup \{ |f(x) - f(x')| : x, x' \in I \}$ [def_2].
• For some $h>0$, $W_f([x_0-h, x_0+h]) < \epsilon$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For all $x, x'$ such that $x, x' \in [x_0-h, x_0+h]$, we have $|f(x) - f(x')| < \epsilon$ [l2].

Therefore, we conclude:
• For that same $h>0$, for all $x \in [a,b]$ such that $|x - x_0| < h$, we have $|f(x) - f(x_0)| < \epsilon$ [l3].
